publicationStmt.idno: Source copy consulted: Oxford, Corpus Christi College, Oxford, MS 201

head.note: This folio marker does not represent a leaf boundary at this point, but it is included to make it possible to display the facsimile image from this passus file.

lg.l: NOwF.4.1: The ornamented capital is produced in red and green ink with flourishes in red to within an inch of the top of the written space. is Meede Ã¾e Mayde / & no mo of alle.
I-browht by-fore Ã¾e kyng / with bedel & bayly
A-non Ã¾e kyng kallid a Clerk / y knowe not his name.
To take Meede Ã¾e Maide / & make hire a teseat ese.
But y wille hire first a-sayÈe / & sotilly hire apose.
What wyÈe of Ã¾is world / Ã¾at she were levest.
& if she wirche be my wit / & my wille folwe.F.4.7: IIIIus with red flourishes is written in the top right margin to indicate the passus.
I wil for-gyve hire Ã¾e gyltisF.4.8: Alpha is responsible for plural gyltis. Beta manuscripts have gilt. / so me god helpe.
Â¶ Ãanne Ã¾e Clerk curteysly / dyde as Ã¾e kyng hym hyghte.

He took Meede by Ã¾e myddil / & menteF.4.10: F alone has this probably original reading. We have not determined whether it represents F-Redactor's (or F-Scribe's) intelligent conjecture or (as Kane and Donaldson have proposed) his access to a pre-archetypal manuscript. hire to chambre.
& Ã¾e Clerk gan conforte hire / for gret conynge he hadde.F.4.11: This line appears only in F.
& fette furÃ¾ merthe with menstralcy / Meede with to plese.
Â¶ Summe Ã¾at whonen at westmenstre / worchepe Ã¾ey hire make.
Ful Ientylly with IoyÈe / of Ã¾e Iustises manye.
Busked hem boldly to hire bour / Ã¾ere Ã¾e beerde dwelliÃ¾.
To conforte hire konyngly / by Clergyes leve.
Ãey seide moorne not Meede / ne make Ã¾ou no sorwe.
For we wille wisse Ã¾e kyng / & Ã¾y weyÈe shape.
To be weddid at Ã¾y wille / & wher Ã¾e levest lykeÃ¾.
For al consyecysconsye[n]cys craft / or castF.4.20: Alpha is responsible for this word order. Beta manuscripts have "cast or craft." / as y trowe.
Â¶ Ãanne MyÈldely Meede / mercyed hem alle.
Of here grete goodnesse / & gaf to hem ecchone.
Cowpis / of klene gold / with cases of syluer.
Ryngis with rubyes / & rycchesseF.4.24: Alpha is responsible for rychesse. Beta manuscripts have richesses. ful thykke.
For Ã¾e leeste of here men / hadde a motoun of goolde.
Ãan lawhte Ã¾ei here leve / Ã¾o Lordis at Meede.
& with Ã¾at ï ¡ kemen Clerkys / & confortid hire Ã¾e same.
& beedyn hire be blythe / For we ben Ã¾yn owene.
For to wirche Ã¾y wille / Ã¾e whyles Ã¾ou may laste.
Ãanne she dede hendely / & be-hyghte hem Ã¾e same.
To loven hem lelly / & Loordis hem to make.
For in Ã¾e constorie in Ã¾e court / I shal do cowÃ¾e Èour name.
Shal no lewidnesse lettyn / Ã¾o clerkysF.4.33: Alpha is responsible for clerkys. Beta manuscripts have leode. Ã¾at y lovye.
Ãat he worÃ¾F.4.34: Bx reads "That he ne worÃ¾ first auaunced . . . ." The negative was omitted in alpha. first a-vauncyd / for y am wel be-knowe.
Ãere Ã¾at konynge clerkys / shulle knokkek[l]okkeF.4.35: F supplies non-sensical knokke to replace klokke, "limp," an unfamiliar word which appears only in Piers Plowman. by-hyÈnde.
Â¶ Ãanne com Ã¾ere a Confessoure / was coped as a Frere.

To Meede Ã¾atF.4.37: Beta witnesses read Ã¾e, exactly what Langland's usual formula would suggest. However, R has Ã¾is, and alpha may simply have had a thorn without the suspended <s>, <t>, or <e>. Mayde / & meelyde Ã¾ese wordis.
& seyde ful softly / as in scryfte it where.
Ãey leernede men / & lewede men / have leyn by Ã¾e boÃ¾e.
& Ã¾ey Fals have defoulyd Ã¾e / Ã¾is fyftene wynter.
I shal a-soyle Ã¾e my-selue / for a seem of wheete.
& also ben Ã¾yn bedeman / & beere wel Ã¾yn name.
A-mongys Clerkys & knyghtys / here consyence to turne.
Â¶ Ãan Meede for hire mysdedis / to Ã¾at man turnede.
& shrof hire of hire shrewidnesse / shameles y trowe.
Whan she hadde told hire tale / she took hym a noble.
For to been hire bedeman / & hire brokour alse.
Â¶ A-non he assoylyd hire soone / & sytthen he seyde.
We have a wyndowe wirchynge / wille sytte vs ful hyÈe
Wolde Èe glase Ã¾at gable / & grave Ã¾ere-In Èoure name.
Sykirly sholde Èoure soule / in-to hevene styÈe.

Â¶ Èee wiste y Ã¾at quod Meede / Ã¾er is[n]is wyndowe ne awhter.F.4.52: This line and the following one correspond roughly to A 3.50-51. Alpha omits eleven lines attested by beta witnesses. Possibly the addition of this line and the next reflects alpha's attempts to restore material missing in his exemplar from his memory of A. Beta reads as follows:
Wiste I Ã¾at quod Ã¾at womman I wolde noÈt spare
For to be youre frend frere and faile yow neuere
While ye loue lordes Ã¾at lecherie haunten
And lakkeÃ¾ noÈt ladies Ã¾at louen wel Ã¾e same
It is a freletee of flessh ye fynden it in bokes
And a cours of kynde wherof we comen alle
Who may scape Ã¾e sclaundre Ã¾e scaÃ¾e is soone amended
It is synne of Ã¾e seuene sonnest relessed
Haue mercy quod Mede of men Ã¾at it haunteÃ¾
And I shal couere youre kirk youre cloistre do maken
Wowes do whiten and wyndowes glazen.
Ãat yy [ne] wolde do mende it / or make it at Ã¾e fulle.

& do peynte me & myn name / a-pertly Ã¾ere-InneF.4.54: The line is unique to F. Beta reads "Do peynten and portraye and paie for Ã¾e makynge." F is possibly influenced by A's "Ãat I ne shulde make or mende & myn name writen."

Ãat ech aF.4.55: Alpha is responsible for ech a. Beta manuscripts have euery. segge sholde see / I am syster to Èow alle.F.4.55: Alpha is responsible for "to Èow alle." Beta manuscripts have "of youre house."
/ [Â¶] But god / to goode folk / swich grauynge defendiÃ¾.
& wrytynge in wyndowis / of here wel-dedys.
Ne awhter do peynte / for pompe of Ã¾e peple.F.4.58: The line is unique to F. Beta reads "An auenture pride be peynted Ã¾ere and pomp of Ã¾e world."
For crist knoweth Ã¾yn consyence / & Ã¾yn kende wille.

BoÃ¾e Ã¾e coost & Ã¾y coueytyse / & who Ã¾e catel awhte.F.4.60: F omits the following lines from Bx:
ForÃ¾i I lere yow lordes leueÃ¾ swiche werkes
To writen in wyndowes of youre wel dedes
Or to greden after goddes men whan ye delen doles
On auenture ye haue youre hire here and youre heuene als.
The lines are missing from H as well.

hi.hi: esciat sinistra ï ¡ quid faciat dextera.

lg.l: Leete nowht Ã¾yn lyft half / neyÃ¾ir late ne rathe.
Weetyn what Ã¾ou wyrchist / with Ã¾yn ryght syde.
For Ã¾us biddis Ã¾e gospel / good men dosdo[n]F.4.64: F has missed the point, substituting a finite form for the required infinitive. Ã¾erafter.
/ [Â¶] MeyÈres with here Macerys / Ã¾at meenys been be-twene.
Ãe kyng / & Ã¾e Comounys / to kepen wel Ã¾e Lawys.

& punsshynF.4.67: The scribe corrected this word by writing a second <s> over original <c>. See F4.195, 10.561 for similar corrections. vponF.4.67: Alpha is responsible for vpon. Beta manuscripts have on. pylory / & on pynygepyny[n]ge stolys.
BoÃ¾e websteres & bakesterys / & bocheres & Cookys.
For Ã¾o are men vponF.4.69: Alpha is responsible for vpon. Beta manuscripts have on. moolde / Ã¾at mest harm wirche.
To Ã¾e poore peple / Ã¾at parcel-meel byggyn.
& poysene Ã¾e peple / pryvyly & softe.
Ãey rychen Ã¾oru regratrye / & rentys hem byggyn
With Ã¾at ï ¡ Ã¾e pore peple / sholde pytte in here wombe.
For tooke Ã¾ey on trewly / Ã¾ey tyÈmbred not so hyÈe.
Ne bowhte no bargayn / be Ã¾eF.4.75: This alpha reading is shared by BmBoCot; most other beta manuscripts have ye. fulle serteyn.
Â¶ But now Ã¾e Maide meede / Ã¾e Mayr haÃ¾ she prayed.
Of alle swiche selleres / syluer to taken.
Or presentys with-outyn pens / as pecys of syluer.
Or rynges or rycchesse / Ã¾e regratoures to meynghtemeyn[ten]e.
For my LordF.4.80: Alpha reads Lord for Bx's loue. / quod Ã¾at Lady / loveÃ¾ hem ecchone.
& suffreÃ¾ hem to selle / sumdel a-geyn resoun
/ [Â¶] Kyng Salomon Ã¾e sage / a sermoun he made.
To a-Mende MeyÈhrys / & men Ã¾at kepe Ã¾e Lawis
& Ã¾us he tolde his teeme / Ã¾at y shal telle Èou after.

hi.hi: gnis deuorabit tabernacula eorum qui libenter

l.note: F.4.85: Alpha omits beta's accipiunt munera.

lg.l: A-mong lettryd leedis / Ã¾is latyn ys to meene.
Ãat feer shal falle & brenne / al to bloo askys.
Ãe howses / & Ã¾e homes / of hem Ã¾at dysyren.
Gyftys / or Èeris-gyftys / be-cause of here offyÈs.F.4.89: Alpha is responsible for offyÈs, a reading shared by H. Beta manuscripts have plural offices.
Â¶ Ãanne Ã¾e kyng fram conseyl cam / & callyd after Meede.
& sente after hire swyÃ¾e / with sergauntys manye.
Ãat browhtynbrowhtyn [hire] to bowre / wiÃ¾ blysse & with IoyÈe.
/ [Â¶] A-non Ã¾e kyng curteysly / comsed for to telle.
& to Meede Ã¾e Maide / he melede Ã¾ese wordis.
Ãou womman vn-wittyly / wrought hast Ã¾ou ofte.
But worse wroughtist Ã¾ou neuere / Ã¾an whan Ã¾ou fals tooke.
But y forgyve Ã¾e Ã¾at gylt / & graunte Ã¾e myn grace.
Fram hens to Ã¾yn deÃ¾-day / yf Ã¾ou do so no moore.
/ [Â¶] But y have a knyght hatte consyence / kam late fram by-Èounde.
If he wilne Ã¾e to wyve / wilt Ã¾ou with hym holde.
Â¶ Èee Lord quod Ã¾e Lady / oure Lord for-beede ellys.
But y be holly at Èour heste / hyÈe hangehange [me] soone.
/ [Â¶] & Ã¾an was Consyence clepd / to comen & a-peren.
By-fore Ã¾e kyng & his cunseyl / as Clerkys & oÃ¾ere.
Â¶ Ãanne Consience knelynge / vnto Ã¾e kyng lowhtede.
To wete what his wille were / & what he do sholde.
/ [Â¶] Wilt Ã¾ou weddyn Ã¾is womman quod Ã¾e kyng / if she wille a-sente.
For she is of fair shapF.4.108: F's reading is unique. Beta manuscripts read "fayn of Ã¾i felaweshipe." / for to ben Ã¾yn make.
Â¶ Quod Consience to Ã¾e kyng / crist it me for-beede.
& er y wedde swich a wyf / woo me by-tyÈde.
For she is fykel of feyÃ¾ / & fals of hire speche.
& makÃ¾ men mys-doon / manye skore tyÈmes.
& Ã¾o Ã¾at tristne on trewÃ¾e / she treyÈeÃ¾ hem ofte.F.4.113: F's line is unique. Bx reads "Trust of hire tresor trayeÃ¾ ful manye."
BoÃ¾e wyvis & wedewis / & wantowne wenchis.F.4.114: The b- verse is unique to F. Bx reads "wantounnesse she techeÃ¾."
& lerneÃ¾ hem Leccherye / Ã¾at loveÃ¾ hire loore.
Èowre fader she felde / Ã¾orhÈ hireF.4.116: BmBoCot read hire, which is otherwise unique to F. fayreF.4.116: Alpha is responsible for fayre. Beta manuscripts read false. heste.
& she haÃ¾ y-poysoned popis / & a-peyred holy chirche
Ãer is nawht a bettre bawde / by hym Ã¾at me maade.
By-twexe hevene & helle / Ã¾ey men al erthe sowhte.
For she is tykyl of hire tayl / & talewyÈs of tunge.
& as comoune as cartewey / to ech knave of towhne.
She takÃ¾ MasonysF.2.122: F's reading "She takÃ¾ Masonys" is unique. Other manuscripts have "To Monkes." F also uniquely has & twice in place of Bx's to. & Menstralys / & Meselys in heggys.
BoÃ¾e Sysoures & Sumnowres / swiche shulle hire preyse.
But Sherevis of Shyres / wheryn shent if she neere.
For she doÃ¾ men leesen here lond / & here lyf boÃ¾e.
& she leetyÃ¾ passe prisonerys / & payeÃ¾ for hem ofte.
& gyfÃ¾ Ã¾e gailer gold / & grootys to-gydre.
To vnfetere Ã¾e false / & flee where hym lykeÃ¾.
& trewÃ¾e ys take be Ã¾e top / & teyÈed fyÈn faste.
& he hangyd for hatterede / Ã¾at harm dyde neuere.
To don curse in constorye / she a-counteÃ¾ not a resshe.

For she copeÃ¾ Ã¾e Comyssarie / & klokiÃ¾F.4.132: klokiÃ¾, "provides with a cloak." This is the first instance we have found of the finite form of this verb. OED's earliest citations are from the early sixteenth century, while the only MED citation is a participial adjective dated c. 1450 in the related sense "encased, enclosed." alle hise clerkys.
& she ys a-soyled soone / as hire-selue lykyÃ¾.
Â¶ She may neeyh doon as myche / in a MoneÃ¾ ones.
As Èowre secret seel / sire kyng / in sixe skore dayes.
For she is prive with Ã¾e pope / alle provisoures it knoweÃ¾.
For Maister Symony & hire-selue / a-seelyn Ã¾e billys

& she blessiÃ¾ bisshopis / & beggerys she hateÃ¾. A problem in alpha has led F to invent new b-verses for these two lines. Beta witnesses attest:
She blesseÃ¾ Ã¾ise Bisshopes Ã¾eiÈ Ã¾ei be lewed
Prouendreth persones, and preestes maynteneÃ¾
& prestys she meynteneÃ¾ / with mennes wifes to deele.
& to have lemannysF.4.140: F alone begins the line with & and omits and lotebies. / alle here lyf-dayes.
& so ben browht forÃ¾ barnes / a-geyn for-boode Lawis.
/ [Â¶] & Ã¾ere she is weel with Ã¾e kyng / woo ys / to Ã¾at Rewhme.
For she is fauerable / to Fals / & defouleÃ¾ trewÃ¾e ofte.
By Iesus with hire Iewelis / Ã¾eF.4.144: Alpha is responsible for Ã¾e. Beta manuscripts have youre. Iustises she shendiÃ¾.
& lyÈeÃ¾ a-geyn Ã¾e Lawhe / & lettyÃ¾ so Ã¾e gate.
Ãat feyÃ¾ may not have his furÃ¾ / for Floreynys goo so Ã¾ykke.
She leediÃ¾ Ã¾e lawe as she lyst / & swiche love-dayes makeÃ¾.
Ãat men leese be hire love / Ã¾at lawe wolde Ã¾ey wonne.
Èee Ã¾e Mase for a meene man / Ã¾eyhÈ he moote euere.
For Ã¾e Lawe is so lordly / & looÃ¾ to make an ende.
With-outyn presentys or pens / it plesiÃ¾ but fewe.
Â¶ BoÃ¾e Baronys & burgeisis / she bryngiÃ¾ in sorwe.
& alle Ã¾e comonis in care / Ã¾at coueyten truthe.
For Clergye & Coueytyse / she cowpleÃ¾ to-gydre.
Ãis is Ã¾e Lyf of Ã¾at Lady / oure Lord gyve hire sorwe.
& allealle [Ã¾at] hire meyntene & hire men / myschawnce hem by-tyÈde.
For poore men have no powher / to pleyne Ã¾eyhÈ Ã¾ey smerte.F.4.157: F omits the following line from Bx: "Swich a maister is Mede among men of goode."

THanneF.4.158: A small guide <t> for the rubricator appears to the top left of the finished <T>. mornede Meede / & made mychil sorwe.F.4.158: F combines and reconfigures Bx's b-verse with the a-verse of the following line. Bx reads as follows:
Thanne mournede Mede and mened hire to Ã¾e kynge
To haue space to speke spede if she myÈte.
& prayede Ã¾e kyng to speke / speede if she myghte.
Ãe kyng grauntyd hire grace / with a glad wille.
Excuse Ã¾e if Ã¾ou canst / I can no moore . Ã¾is tyme.
For Consience haÃ¾ accused Ã¾e ï ¡ to kunge Ã¾e for euere.
Nay Lord quod Ã¾at Lady / now leve hym Ã¾e worse
Whan Èee wetyn wyttyrly / where Ã¾e wrong lyggiÃ¾.
For Ã¾ere Ã¾at Mischeef ys gret / Meede may it helpe.
& Ã¾atF.4.166: Alpha is responsible for Ã¾at. Beta manuscripts lack it. Ã¾ou knowist Consience / y can not with Ã¾e chyde.
Ne deprave Ã¾y persone / with a prowd herte.
But wel Ã¾ou woost wernard / but if Ã¾ou wylle gabbe.
Ãou hast hangid on myn half / eleuene tymes.
& also y-gripe my gold / & gyve ytF.4.170: An otiose tilde appears above the <y>. where Ã¾e lyked.
But why ï ¡ Ã¾ou wratthest Ã¾e now / wondir me Ã¾ynkyÃ¾.
For Èit y may as y myghte / menske Ã¾e with gyftys.
& meyntene Ã¾yn manhod / moore Ã¾an Ã¾ou knowyst.
But Ã¾ou hast defameddefamed [me] foule / by-fore Ã¾e kyng heere.
For truly y kyllyde neuere knyghtF.4.175: Alpha is responsible for knyght. Beta manuscripts have kyng. / ne contrivede Ã¾at dede.
Ne dyde as Ã¾ou demest me / y doo it on Ã¾e dede.F.4.176: F has picked up dede from the preceding line. Bx has kynge.
Â¶ For in NormondyÈ Ã¾e kyng was nout / noyhed for my sake

But Ã¾ou Ã¾y-selve sothly / Ã¾ou shamedist hym ofte.F.4.178: The top of the page has a five-line illustration with a human head at the left end of a decorated tube and a lion's head at the right end. The drawing incorporates the ascenders from the text.
For cropeCrope in a Caban / for cold of Ã¾yn naylys.
& wendist Ã¾at wynter / wolde have lasted euere.
& also Ã¾ou dreddist to dyÈe / for a dym clowhde.
& hyÈedist homwarde / for hungir of Ã¾y wombe.
Â¶ & with-outyn pyte Ã¾ou pylour / pore men Ã¾ou robbedist.F.4.183: An otiose curl appears over the <o>.
& bere here bras at Ã¾y bak / In Caleys to selle.
Ãere y lefte with my Lord / his lyf for to save.
I made hise men meryÈe / & here Murnynge y lette.
I batered hem on Ã¾e bak / & bolded here hertys.
& dide hem hoppyn on hope / to have me at wille.
Â¶ Hadde y be Marchal of hise men / be Marie of hevene.
I durste haue leyd my lyf / & no lesse gage.
He shulde havehave [be] lord of Ã¾at lond / in lengÃ¾e & in brede.
& also kyng of Ã¾at kyÃ¾ / al his keen to helpe.
Ãe leeste brolle of Ã¾is londF.4.193: The substitution of lond for Bx's blood is owed to alpha. / a baronys peere.
Â¶ & Ã¾ou Consience / cowardly / Ã¾ou conseyledist hym Ã¾enne.
To levyn so his LordshepeF.4.195: The scribe initially wrote Lordchepe and then corrected the <c> to <s>. Cf. F4.67, 10.561. / for a lytyl syluer.
Ãat ys Ã¾e ryccheste regne / Ã¾at reyÈn ouere-hoveÃ¾.
It be-comeÃ¾ wel a kyng / Ã¾at kepiÃ¾ a rewhme.
To Èyve Meede to men / Ã¾at menskly hym serue.
& alyenys & oÃ¾ire men / to honoure hem with gyftys.
For Meede makÃ¾ hym by-loved / & a man y-holde.
Â¶ Emperoures / & Erlys / & alle erthely Lordis.
ÃorghÈ Èiftys have ÈoomenF.4.202: Alpha is responsible for Èoomen. Beta manuscripts have yonge men. / to Èeerne & to ryÈde.
Â¶ Ãe Pope also / of prelatys / presentys he vndir-fongyÃ¾.
& Ã¾ey Meede men hem-selue / to meyntene Ã¾e lawis.
& seruauntys for here seruyse / who can seyÈ Ã¾e sothe.
Take Meede of here Mayster / as Ã¾ey moun a-corde.
& beggerys for here beggyngF.4.207: Alpha is responsible for beggyng. Beta manuscripts have biddynge. / byddyn for men meede.
& Menstralis for here merthe / meede / men hem profre.
/ [Â¶] Ãe kyng haÃ¾ Meede of hise men / to make pees in londe.
& men Ã¾at techen chyldryn / craven of hem meede.F.4.210: A pointing finger is added in the margin by a later hand.
Preestis Ã¾at preche Ã¾e peple / of god Ã¾ey aske meede.
& messe-pens & here meel / at here mete tyÈme.
Alle manere of crafty men / crave meede for here prentyÈs.
& Marchauntys & meede / muste nedys goon to-gydre.
No wyÈht as y wene / withoutyn meede may lybbe.

F.4.216: This ornamental capital, more elaborate than the one at 4.158, is red with green flourishes. A small guide <t> is visible in its midst. Than seyde Ã¾e kyng to consience / by crist as me Ã¾ynkiÃ¾.
Now ys Meede worthy / Ã¾e Maystrie to have.
Â¶ Nay quod consience to Ã¾e kyng / & kneled on Ã¾e erÃ¾e.
Ãere ben two manere of meedis / my lord be Èour leve.
Ãe firste is Ã¾at god of his grace / grauntyÃ¾ to his blysse.
To Ã¾o Ã¾at wel wirche / whilis Ã¾ey ben on erthe.
Ãe prophete prechiÃ¾ Ã¾er-of / & is pyt in Ã¾e Sawter.

hi.hi: Domine quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo ï ¡ atque quis requiescet in monte sancto eius . imocensi[nn]ocens manibus & mundo corde.

l.note: F.4.223: F significantly augments the tag. Bx ends after tuo.

lg.l: He seyÃ¾ Lord who shal wone in Ã¾yn wones / with Ã¾yn holy seyntis.
Er restyn on Ã¾yn holy hillis / Ã¾us askedeF.4.225: Alpha is responsible for askede. Beta manuscripts have askeÃ¾. dauyd.
/ [Â¶] & dauyd asoyled it / hym-selue / as Ã¾e sawhter tellyÃ¾.

hi.hi: Qui ingreditur sine macula ï ¡ & operatur iusticiam.

lg.l: Ão Ã¾at entryn of o colour he seiÃ¾ / & also of o wille.
& haven wroght werkis / with ryght & with resoun.
& he wil nowht vse / Ã¾e lyf of vseryÈe.
But en-formeÃ¾ pore men / to pursue trewÃ¾e.F.4.231: F omits Bx's "Qui pecuniam suam non dedit ad vsuram et munera super innocentem."
& Ã¾o Ã¾at helpe Ã¾e Innocent / & holde with Ã¾e ryghtful.
& with-outyn Meede doon hem good / & trew menF.4.233: Alpha is responsible for trew. Beta manuscripts have truÃ¾e. F alone adds men. helpe.
Swiche manere of men my lord / shulle have Ã¾e for-seyd mede.
Of god / at his grete neede / whan Ã¾ey goon hennys.
/[Â¶] Ãe seconde Meede ys Mesourles / Ã¾at Maystris dysyren
To Meyntene mysdoerys / Meede Ã¾ey taken.
